ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Python coding and shallow level of skill in packages
How to code in Python.
I learned about Python packages including numpy, pandas, pytorch, and networkx. I learned about the use of gradient descent and stochastic gradient descent in machine learning.
None
As a senior taking this in his last semester, I did not gain much new knowledge or skills beyond more practice with Python

You learn about a huge breadth of topics having to do with data science, particularly mathematical models for machine learning and their implementation in code. You also learn a few cool python libraries too. If you stay on top of the material, its very rewarding.
Learned various python packages
Knowledge of some more Python modules and tools. How to implement them, and familiarity with some common datasets.
A basic overview of the math, methods, and tools of data science and engineering
PCA, SVD, etc. Basically, this class is doing linear algebra in Python.
I was exposed to different concepts in data science.

Gained a better understanding of some data science concepts like PCA, linear regression, neural networks, SVD, etc. Also got a bit better at Python programming through the use of many data science packages.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The Jupiter notebook lecture format is really not a great form for online learning. It was very hard to focus and keep track and follow along when lectures were just Jupiter notebooks running code
Lectures were not very engaging but the problem sets were doable with help in office hours.

The topics in this course are interesting and important, but lectures were extremely dull. By far the most engaging classes were when students grouped up to work on coding tasks together. Seeing as this course is so much about practical data science skills, I think more opportunities for students to practice together would be very helpful. Also, given that the lectures and assignments are based entirely on the professor's notes, those notes should be as organized and error-free as possible, and should contain references for further reading.

The course was a disaster. Disorganized, lectures and handouts full of mistakes. Office hours were poorly managed and help wasnt available beyond the trite advice, try the simplest thing for every kind of problem. Avoid this class.

Strengths: introduction to a range of data science concepts
Weaknesses: organization of course logistics (having pre-determined due dates for psets before the semester started, rather than announcing pset due dates along the way), presentation of material not very cohesive (unclear what the connection was between each of the separate things we learned), lecture was not very strong (sometimes lacked a fluid presentation of the material, lecture style was rambly and at times hard to understand what was important to take away)

The class was very well organized. All code was posted on the class github, and the professor even uploaded (I assume latex) pdfs for the really mathematical content. Students also got a lot of autonomy, which meant the class could be chill and informative if you let it.
Lectures were not always engaging and at the beginning the expectations for participation though online forums was unclear.

Strengths: prof is really passionate and tries hard to make the class a good environment for student learning. Homeworks are interesting and fun without being too difficult, and allow you to really pick up the skills.
Disadvantages: The main way the lecture is taught is by throwing up Jupyter notebooks on screen and running through blocks of code to see how they work. Fundamentally, I don't really think it's a great teaching methodology, to just show students the code running while throwing in a bit of explanation. Since I already have a lot of background in Python, I actually found it fairly easy to not pay attention in lecture, because you could do the homeworks and pick up the same skills just by reading the docs.
A strength was that the psets were very interesting and I felt like I learned a lot from them. A weakness that could be improved was how organized the course was.

Strengths: I liked how there were not any exams in the course, and it was just the problem sets and HWX. The problem sets, although hard (probably 15-20 hours every other week), were truly representative of what we learn in class.

Weakness: Professor Lederman is a nice guy, but he can be hard to work with at times. Whenever I or someone else would ask a question on Github, 90 percent of the time he would tell us to google our problem (Even though many students do google it before asking). At many times he didn't really like to give help/hints.
More ULA office hours. The psets are hard and the OH werent at convinient times.

Strength: If you're into data science and like Python, then definitely this course will be for you. A lot of the material covered is very relevant to data science and it focuses not just on programming but also a bit on the fundamental concepts like Linear algebra and SVD. Weakness: Some of the grading is a bit arbitrary and unreasonable at times where lots of points are taken off for minor mistakes.

The actual material of the course is important and useful to know for anyone interested in statistics! However, the class itself was not extremely engaging, and lectures were not particularly helpful in learning the content. The problem sets were often confusing and Professor Lederman was not great at explaining more confusing aspects of the course. The choice to just scroll through code while not explaining what it did and the theory about it didn't make much sense. Some of the linear algebra concepts were confusing, and it would have been helpful for Professor Lederman to cover the basics before jumping into complex mathematical theory. The integration of GitHub into the class was interesting, but it would have been nice to be able to collaborate more freely given the type of material/how those projects would be completed in practical situations.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Jupiter notebooks for p sets are good and help learn, not for lectures though
The most effective virtual teaching strategy was when students were assigned to work on practice problems in breakout rooms.
Recorded lectures are great.

It didn't seem necessary for attendance at lecture to be necessary given that there was little to no engagement. It was frustrating given timezones/etc. for live attendance to be required when lectures were recorded and not personally engaging.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: If they can refine the lectures and way the course is delivered I dont feel like I got what I wanted out of the class. It kept jumping around tools not really going at all into actual methods.
Yes, if you want to learn Pandas, PyTorch and other packages in Python.

If you're ok teaching yourself most of the material, then I think this course will provide a bunch of interesting topics for you to explore. But if you're expecting a well-organized walk-through of data science tools, maybe look elsewhere.

The lectures were not the most interesting and the class itself often felt muddled and disorganized. However, the topics and psets were interesting and workload was not excessive. It gives good practice in Python an JupyterNotebook.
Absolutely not, unless it is taught by a different professor. This is the worst course I have taken at Yale.

I wouldn't recommend this course to someone else unless they were a stats major and wanted an easy class for their last semester. I think other courses are much more organized and with better lectures than 262 with Roy and which offer similar skills and material. If you're looking for a good intro to the stats major, I highly recommend 230 with JDRS and not this course. If you want to learn Python there are other courses that do a better job (e.g. 365) or learn it on your own time (really easy to do so if you've already taken a class that requires coding in another language, e.g. 230). 262 was not a challenge for me, because I took this in my last semester for the stats major, but if I were seeing this material for the first time, I probably would've been much more confused. I don't think 262 really taught the material well either so that's why other classes are probably better
Definitely! If you like math and want to learn about models for data science, this is your class. You might want to make sure youre up to speed on linear algebra first.

If you're an S&DS major, then this is the best way to fulfill the categort B requirement, imo. If you have a little experience in Python and don't have motivation to learn more on your own, but want to anyway, this might be right for you. Otherwise, I don't recommend it.

I would recommend this course to another student only if they had completed the prerequisite classes. I took one of the prerequisites (Linear Algebra) at the same time as this class (which was allowed) but I felt like I was at a disadvantage in the class because of it.
I would recommend this course to another student; however, I would recommend that you have a pretty manageable course load because this class can take some time.

If you have a strong python background & have been exposed to data science already I think its a good course. You browse over concepts quickly so most of the things you learn wont really stick with you unless you use it often.
If you need it to fulfill a requirement, you need it to fulfill a requirement. Roy is super kind but honestly I had a hard time learning in this course / receiving clear instructions.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Jupiter notebooks
n/a
The lectures were also recorded
Ed discussions, Git hub discussions
Technically the lecture was meant to be live, as there were sometimes in-person components, but most of the time it would have been possible to watch asynchronously.
Office hours
Live virtual lectures were recorded.
recorded lecture
The lectures were available as recordings after the fact.
